channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: DOGE saved far less than claimed. And, Trump blames Zelenskyy for Russia's invasion
item.description: An online tracker claims DOGE has saved $55 billion in federal spending, but NPR has found this to be false. And, Trump blames the Ukrainian president for Russia's invasion.
item.content:encoded:
An online tracker claims DOGE has saved $55 billion in federal spending, but NPR has found this to be false. And, Trump blames the Ukrainian president for Russia's invasion. 

(Image credit: Jim Watson)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: China repatriates more than 1,000 online scam workers rescued from Myanmar
item.description: Thailand, China and Myanmar have coordinated efforts over the past month to shut down the scam centers that bilked victims around the world out of billions of dollars.
item.content:encoded:
Thailand, China and Myanmar have coordinated efforts over the past month to shut down the scam centers that bilked victims around the world out of billions of dollars.

(Image credit: Sarot Meksophawannakul)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: A gold-framed Trump mug shot is hanging just outside of the Oval Office
item.description: President Trump's mug shot is one of the first things visitors will see when approaching the Oval Office.
item.content:encoded:
New York Post is framed in an office just outside the Oval Office.'/>

President Trump's mug shot is one of the first things visitors will see when approaching the Oval Office.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: How Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum could hit you at the grocery store
item.description: U.S. tariffs could cause the prices of steel and aluminum cans to rise, an increase that may ultimately be passed on to consumers.
item.content:encoded:
U.S. tariffs could cause the prices of steel and aluminum cans to rise, an increase that may ultimately be passed on to consumers.

(Image credit: Spencer Platt)
item.dc:creator: Joe Hernandez

item.title: A military vet and a scientist were securing America's food system. Trump fired them
item.description: More than 10,000 federal employees who had yet to complete their probationary periods have been fired by the Trump administration, including those who work to protect American agriculture.
item.content:encoded:
More than 10,000 federal employees who had yet to complete their probationary periods have been fired by the Trump administration, including those who work to protect American agriculture.

(Image credit: Alyssa Pointer for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Andrea Hsu

item.title: Black farmers among those left in limbo amid federal funding freeze
item.description: The federal government has historically discriminated against Black farmers. The recent funding halt from the Trump administration presents yet another hurdle to those who have spent decades fighting for equity in farming.
item.content:encoded:
The federal government has historically discriminated against Black farmers. The recent funding halt from the Trump administration presents yet another hurdle to those who have spent decades fighting for equity in farming.

(Image credit: Dee Dwyer)
item.dc:creator: Marisa Peñaloza

item.title: First known cookbook by a Black American woman gets new edition 160 years later
item.description: Malinda Russell's A Domestic Cookbook was first published in 1866. It contains least a hundred recipes for sweets, plus recipes for shampoo and cologne – and remedies for toothaches.
item.content:encoded: Malinda Russell's A Domestic Cookbook was first published in 1866. It contains least a hundred recipes for sweets, plus recipes for shampoo and cologne – and remedies for toothaches.
item.dc:creator: Neda Ulaby

item.title: Hamas releases the bodies of four Israeli hostages, including mother and young sons
item.description: Today's release is the first time Hamas has handed over the bodies of hostages during the war, although several have been recovered by Israeli forces in Gaza and returned to Israel.
item.content:encoded:
Today's release is the first time Hamas has handed over the bodies of hostages during the war, although several have been recovered by Israeli forces in Gaza and returned to Israel.

(Image credit: Abdel Kareem Hana)
item.dc:creator: Kat Lonsdorf

item.title: Panama sends 97 U.S. deportees to migrant camp after they refused to be repatriated
item.description: The migrants refused to be repatriated to their countries. They will be held in a migration facility near the Darien Gap along the Colombian border until third countries can be found to take them.
item.content:encoded:
The migrants refused to be repatriated to their countries. They will be held in a migration facility near the Darien Gap along the Colombian border until third countries can be found to take them.

(Image credit: Agustin Herrera)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Hegseth directs Pentagon to find $50 billion in cuts this year
item.description: The cuts would be as drastic as sequestration in 2013, the law passed by Congress that forced the armed services to cut $56 billion in a matter of months.
item.content:encoded:
The cuts would be as drastic as sequestration in 2013, the law passed by Congress that forced the armed services to cut $56 billion in a matter of months.

(Image credit: Virginia Mayo)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
